rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I took PHYS 118 with Sean over summer session 1, and I have got to say that he is one of the best science professors I have had at UNC. If you don't understand something, he will explain it again and again (in a different way each time), until you understand it. He encourages questions, and is a very fair professor.

When you are new to the material, you may get a sense that Sean's explanations are hasty and incomplete but you'll second guess yourself: "maybe it's just me, maybe I should focus on this lecture and then I'll get it". Wrong - his explanations truly are hasty and incomplete. Come to class, take detailed notes, but learn from TEXTBOOKS W SOLUTIONS!
Respectable professor. If you need help, he will make time. Behind the sarcasm, he's a great professor.
Horrible lecturer.  Makes you feel terrible for asking questions. Avoid.
Made it clear from day 1 he didn't care about this class or anyone in it. Scheduled appointments with him 4 times and he didn't bother to show up every time.
One of the best professors at the University.
Boo.
I had a lot of trouble in this class but I'm not a Physics person. Sometimes he didn't explain things very well. But he was really nice and laid back. A lot of people got As and Bs in there.

Sean is a very awsome and funny guy, however he was a pretty horrible 101 teacher (but he hates that class, so he is a much better teacher in 103).  He makes you feel like he hates answering your questions and that you are really really dumb, but in fact he loves when you ask him questions and just likes picking on you, that's his natural state :P.

Very approachable and friendly. Truly cares about you understanding the material. Lectures are difficult to decipher sometimes, and he has a habit of making you feel dumb if you don't immediately grasp concepts. Office hours are a must. Tests are HARD, but there's a generous curve.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I think I fell asleep in the class almost every day.  Class is very boring and lecture material is completely irrelevant to assignments. He can be funny, but you are usually asleep for those parts.  No clue on how he calculates final grades.
This was a seminar class on Peak Oil. Cecil droned on and on about charts Al Gore style then gives out physics-based assignments (your only grades) with no relevance to lecture. Don't take.

Those who actually attended class usually fell asleep after 10 minutes.  The lectures are basically powerpoints and the poor guy seems depressed all the time.  Seems like he loathes teaching basic astronomy to apathetic freshmen.  Some classmates found it tough, so only take it if you're good at the sciences.
This was a first year seminar on energy, and it wasn't good.  I would not recommend taking the class.  Professor Cecil knows what he's talking about, but he wasn't good at getting us to know it.
really hard tests. he's a funny guy, but a really boring class. you don't have to go to class, but it might help, i didn't go b/c i couldn't stay awake.

There isn't much class work involved in this class. We sometimes had one assignment due per week. The tests seem impossible but there is a pretty generous curve. This class is interesting for the most part but I've fallen asleep multiple times in lecture.
No Comments

He's very scatter-brained and teaches in a very rushed manner. You never know what to expect from him - he forgot our only test and cancelled our semester project. Homework is generally easy except 1 impossible problem. The class is very generously graded. He leaves the country frequently but checks his email freuqently, fortunately.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: One of the hardest classes I've had while at UNC. Very few people have an A in this class.

Bad teacher, not very helpful, and tests were poorly written and did not test learning well. I went into this class interested in physics and came out uninterested. I had taken a physics class prior to this one as well, which was much better.
Not clear at all, wastes time during lecture, never says what work she wants on exams then counts off for not doing things exactly her way.

Seriously, UNC, hire a beaver and replace her. It would do so much better than her in lecturing. Not helpful, incredibly monotone and boring, inconsistent and opaque grading system. But too bad, she's the only one available for the course

Showed poor understanding of material, class consisted of only clicker questions, tests were graded harshly when the student got the correct answer but used a different method than the teacher expected.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Office hours are helpful to a degree. Don't take me wrong, the physics is hard in general. but, she prides herself in giving exams with the highest score in a class of 50 ppl being an 82 and not curving.considers a B or greater to be stellar work. did 450 practice problems just for the final. Still made a B+.(from the organic student who makes ~95)

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: PHYS 119 is tough. Henning was good one-on-one, but in the lecture hall is not too exciting to listen to. He'll tell you what you need to know but doesn't try to make it exciting for you. He also often rants on about why he's teaching how he's teaching instead of just teaching. He'll get the point across, but could easily just do it in fewer words.
Smart and funny guy who is really willing to work with you to help you figure things out.

Professor Henning is about as engaging a physics teacher can get. The lectures go by pretty fast. He's funny which makes the class better along with his ability to explain things. Definitely recommend.

There is a lot of homework. The lectures involve clickers and group disucssions, making it engaging. The labs can be a drag sometimes. There's a lot of material to cover, so it's important to make sure you don't get behind. He explains things pretty clearly.

Professor Henning certainly maximizes his 50 minutes.  Peppered with quirky physics humor, his teaching style is straightforward and well-paced. If you ever find yourself with a question, he happily spends a few minutes discussing it during or after class.  Certainly a good lecturer and highly recommend him for your physics course needs!

Dr. Henning worked hard to ensure the material was better explained and more intuitive than previous introductory level physics classes , and he largely succeeded. The class was difficult, but he seems to be working diligently to continually improve the course. Besides first time kinks, he has created an exemplary model for science classes.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Reichart was fantastic. There was very little homework and the material is super interesting. He's hilarious and I enjoyed his lectures. The class was an easy A but he does throw trick questions on exams. This class does involve math and physics but if you're fairly good at science then you'll  be fine.

This class was supposed to be an easy A, but when he told us top 25% of the class make an A I got really upset. I made a C+ in this class because a lot of students cheated on the final and pushed my grade back. Worst grading scale ever, especially when I worked my butt off for this class. Do NOT recommend for fulfilling a gen-ed.

Reichart is a prof that knows the material backwards and forwards. He's a great guy and hilarious. All of the lectures are found online. The tests are copy and paste from the webassign, just use the webassign answer key and you're good to go. It's a very easy class, he drops lowest test and 2 HW grades. Would recommend for nonscience majors.
Took his Astro 101 class. Gives very clear and informative lectures, but gives tests often on specific trivia that was never covered in class.

Dr. Reichart is an extremely qualified, funny, and kind professor. His lectures are usually very interesting and (except for the telescope selection unit) the material covered is fascinating and will help you better understand the world around you. I took this course purely because it sounded interesting, and would definitely recommend it.

I went to the lectures and used an allowed "cheat sheet"  full of lecture notes and I only passed 1 test. Everything is graded on a curve which sounds great right? Except in any other science course a 70 is a C. In this class a 70 was an F. You had to make in the 80's to get a C. Tests were not on lecture material. They were mostly physics problems
Reichart is a great guy who is very passionate. The class itself is not hard. Just do the homework and make cheat sheets (he allows one per test) for the tests and you will be just fine.

The class sounds like it would be easy, but the cheat sheets barely help because he asks trick questions. Using the textbook to do the homework will get you a zero, he seems to appreciate only his own ideas. When asking him for help he replies with one sentence or nothing at all, and if you go to office hours you better come prepared

Reichart is adorable and funny.  He is very knowledgable about the subject, and you can see that in his excitement for the course.  Class is insanely easy and very interesting.  He drops your lowest test and homework, and if you do an extra credit paper you get a second homework dropped - plus you can bring notes to exams.  Math is minimal and easy

If you are at UNC and looking to take care of your science requirement, this is probably the best science class to take. The professor lets you bring in "cheat sheets" with formulas and information for the multiple choice tests, which are very helpful. Beware - he likes to test on facts/trivia that he mentions once in class and never again.
Reichart he's hard and there's a lot of studying by yourself...

This was a fantastic course, and I absolutely enjoyed Reichart as my professor!!  He's funny, clear in his lectures, and he makes the topics interesting! Take this if you need a science requirement, you'll love it!

Lectures are entertaining, and if you don't want to go he will post them online. If you go to office hours he will all but give you the answers on the homework. He is very very helpful! The only negative things is that he uses web assign, which costs an extra $60, but he will let you use older versions of the text book.

Reichart is a good prof and his lectures were interesting. However, he was not very organized and his notes in class were terrible. The class is graded on a curve, so it only depends how well you do against others. Not a very hard class at all, and easy to get an A or B. Take him if you're interested in astro.

If you are interested at all in astronomy or need a GPA padding course, take Astro 101 with Professor Reichart!  He is extremely funny during lectures (albeit nerdy funny) and the homework is  easy and not time-consuming.  The tests aren't extremely difficult and you get a cheat sheet.  He drops your lowest test grade and 2 lowest homework grades!!

Boring lectures, trick questions on tests and webassign homeworks. only good thing is that you get to have a cheat sheet for exams. Dont take this if you don't have to. He also grades on a weird curve that could hurt you more than help you. Sometimes a 97 on the homeworks is a B. He also doesn't do his own office hours.
Professor Reichart is great! He gives interesting, engaging lectures. All homework is online and all the tests are multiple choice.  He is not very personable however.
We <3 Reichart!!!!

He may be interesting, but he is the most uncaccessible professor! He does not relally like to give A's to his students. He only loves to hear himself. Never avaible during office hours, by the time he responds, you already figured it out, and that could be 2 days. His lab instructor though,  Dr Couze is terrific. By the way, got  a B.
He's awesome. Take the class just to have him. Lecture Notes aren't great, but tests come straight from the online notes and hw, so use that, and take advantage of his cheat sheet rules on each test

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
